Creator Statement: My television series will be based almost completely off of real history. I used accounts of Rozhestvensky’s second-in-command, Vladimir Semenoff, to give me an idea of the arguments of Rozhtesvensky’s crew against him, and to get a sense of their discontent. In Episode 1 of my series, I will start the episode by having Rozhestvensky be living in solitude, something that may have actually happened. Although Rozhestvensky was convicted of negligence once he returned to Russia, historians are still unsure of what his actual punishment was, so I will have to take creative liberty by inventing one. The episode will start the series of flashbacks, which is how I will tell my story. In episode 2, I will cover the Dogger Bank Incident, which actually happened, as Rozhestvensky mistakenly fires on British fishing boats he thought were Japanese destroyers. I will take no liberties in episode 2. In episode 3, I will cover how Britain denied the Baltic Fleet access to its ports, and how upon arriving to the Pacific, the Baltic Fleet engaged in a series of frantic telegrams. While we don’t know for sure if these telegrams happened or not, we do know that telegram contact was used in both the Russian Navy and Russian Army. In episode 4, I will cover the battle of Tsushima, which resulted in the destruction of the Baltic Fleet. As my series is very dramatic, I will take the liberties of romanticizing the battle to make it seem more grand and engaging. In episode 5, my final episode in the series, I will end the series of flashbacks by putting the perspective back to Rozhestvensky as he lives his life next to the ocean that claimed the lives of the men he led for years. I will take no creative liberties with this episode.
Artwork Description: Admiral Zinovy Rozhestvensky, pictured above, headlines the new 6-part series The Baltic Fleet. Coming soon.
